posts.title: Meet the corporation
posts.description: In the following section, the nature, jurisdiction, mission, vision, functions, as well as the regional environmental planning instruments and the institutional characters of Corporinoquia are concisely addressed.

pill.title: CONTENTS
pill.content:
1. Get to know our Corporation

    1.1. Our raison d'être

    1.2. Our Jurisdiction

    1.3. Our corporate image

    1.4. Our Mission

    1.6. Functions

2. Regional environmental planning instruments

    2.1. Regional Environmental Management Plan (PGAR)

pill.title: INTRODUCTION (Welcome)
pill.content:
Welcome:

Hello, for us it is a pleasure to welcome you to our corporation, here you can find relevant information about us, such as our jurisdiction, corporate image, mission, vision, functions and planning instruments, among other information of interest.

We want you to know us and become part of our team, because we are a public corporate body which seeks to implement national policies, plans and programs on environmental issues.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (KNOW OUR CORPORATION)
pill.content:
Our Nature

The Corporación Autónoma Regional de la Orinoquía - CORPORINOQUIA, is a public corporate entity, created by Law 99 of 1993 (this law creates the Ministry of the Environment, reorganizes the Public Sector in charge of the management and conservation of the environment and renewable natural resources, organizes the National Environmental System, SINA, and other provisions are issued).

We are integrated by the territorial entities of jurisdiction, which due to their characteristics geographically constitute the same ecosystem or conform a geopolitical or hydrogeographic unit, endowed with administrative and financial autonomy, own patrimony and legal personality, entrusted by the Law to manage within the area of their jurisdiction the environment and renewable natural resources and to advocate for their sustainable development, in accordance with the legal provisions and the policies of the Ministry of the Environment.

pill.title: SUBJECT DEVELOPMENT (Jurisdiction)
pill.content:
The Corporation has jurisdiction over the entire territory of the Departments of Arauca, Casanare, and Vichada; in the Department of Cundinamarca in the territory of the municipalities of Guayabetal, Quetame, Une, Paratebueno, Chipaque, Cáqueza, Fosca, Gutiérrez, Choachí, and Ubaque; and the municipalities of Pajarito, Labrazangrande, Paya, Pisba, and Cubará in the Department of Boyacá.

The Territorial jurisdiction of the Corporation is made up of 45 municipalities belonging to five departments:

    ➢ Casanare: Yopal, Aguazul, Tauramena, Orocué, Sácama, La Salina, Paz de Ariporo, San Luis de Palenque, Trinidad, Támara,         Recetor, Sabanalarga, Chámeza, Maní, Monterrey, Hato Corozal, Nunchía, Pore and Villanueva.

    ➢ Cundinamarca: Ubaque, Chipaque, Cáqueza, Choachí, Paratebueno, Gutiérrez, Fosca, Guayabetal, Une and Quetame.

    ➢ Arauca: Arauquita, Saravena, Cravo Norte, TAME, Arauca, Puerto Rondón, and Fortul.

    ➢ Boyacá: Cubará, Labranzagrande, Pajarito, Paya and Pisba.

    ➢ Vichada: Cumaribo, Santa Rosalía, Puerto Carreño and La Primavera.

The map of Corporinoquia's jurisdiction is shown below:

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (Our Corporate Image)
pill.content: Below you will find our logo and some examples of our institutional image, which we hope you will recognize every time you see it:

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (Mission and vision)
pill.content:
Mission

Corporinoquia, as environmental authority and administrator of natural resources, manages sustainable development, guaranteeing the supply of environmental goods and services, through the implementation of prevention, protection and conservation actions for a living region.

Vision

By 2024 Corporinoquia will have achieved the environmental and sustainable management of its territory, through the articulated work with the different social actors, harmonizing economic and social development with environmental conservation and the construction of a more competitive region.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (Functions)
pill.content:
The purpose of all Regional Autonomous Corporations is to implement policies, plans, programs and projects on the environment and renewable natural resources, as well as to comply with and timely apply the legal provisions in force on their disposition, administration, management and use, in accordance with the regulations, guidelines and directives issued by the Ministry of the Environment.

By virtue of the above, the functions of Corporinoquia established in Law 99 of 1993. "Whereby the Ministry of the Environment is created, the Public Sector in charge of the management and conservation of the environment and renewable natural resources is reorganized, the National Environmental System, SINA, is organized, and other provisions are issued. Art. 31. Functions of the Corporations are the following:

(Video: What are the Regional Autonomous Corporations).

1. To execute the national policies, plans and programs in environmental matters defined by the law approving the National Development Plan and the National Investment Plan or by the Ministry of the Environment, as well as those of regional order that have been entrusted in accordance with the law, within the scope of their jurisdiction.

2. To exercise the functions of maximum environmental authority, in the area of its jurisdiction, in accordance with the superior norms and in accordance with the criteria and guidelines established by the Ministry of the Environment.

3. To promote and develop community participation in activities and programs for environmental protection, sustainable development and adequate management of renewable natural resources.

4. Coordinate the process of preparation of environmental development plans, programs and projects to be formulated by the different agencies and entities of the National Environmental System SINA in the area of its jurisdiction and, in particular, advise the departments, Districts and Municipalities of its territorial understanding in the definition of environmental development plans and their programs and projects in matters of environmental protection and renewable natural resources, so as to ensure the harmony and coherence of the policies and actions adopted by the different territorial entities.

5. Participate with the other competent agencies and entities within its jurisdiction in the planning and territorial ordinance processes so that the environmental factor is taken into account in the decisions adopted.

6. Enter into contracts, agreements and co-finance with territorial entities, other public and private entities and non-profit entities whose purpose is the defense and protection of the environment and renewable natural resources, in order to better execute some or some of its functions, when they do not correspond to the exercise of administrative functions.

7. To promote and carry out jointly with the national agencies attached and linked to the Ministry of the Environment, and with the technical and scientific support entities of the National Environmental System (SINA), studies and research on environmental and renewable natural resources matters.

8. To advise territorial entities in the formulation of formal environmental education plans and execute non-formal environmental education programs, in accordance with national policy guidelines.

9. To grant concessions, permits, authorizations and environmental licenses required by law for the use, exploitation or mobilization of renewable natural resources or for the development of activities that affect them. To advance in coordination with the authorities of the indigenous communities and with the authorities of the lands traditionally inhabited by black communities, referred to in Law 70 of 1993, programs and projects for sustainable development and for the management, exploitation, use and conservation of renewable natural resources and the environment or that may affect the environment. To grant permits and concessions for the use of surface and subway waters and to establish closures for hunting and sport fishing. This function is developed in accordance with the provisions of paragraph 5. Article 31 of Law 99 of 1993.

10. To implement and operate Environmental Information Systems in the area of its jurisdiction, in accordance with the guidelines established by the Ministry of the Environment.

To visualize the other 27 functions of Corporinoquia click on the following link:

https://corporinoquia.gov.co/images/docsPdf/136721092005.pdf

gallery.title: What are the regional autonomous corporations?

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (REGIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL PLANNING INSTRUMENTS)
pill.content:
Next, we present the environmental planning instruments that, in compliance with the law, have been developed in Corporinoquia's jurisdiction and in whose design and implementation Corporinoquia participates. Then, the effective capacity of this set of instruments to guide the processes of land use and occupation along environmentally sustainable paths is analyzed.

Regional Environmental Management Plan (PGAR): Defined by Decree 1200 of 2004, it is "the long-term strategic planning instrument of the regional autonomous corporations for the area under their jurisdiction (10 years), which allows guiding their management and integrating the actions of all regional actors so that the development process advances towards the sustainability of the regions.

The PGAR 2013-2025 was adopted by resolution No. 1100.02.2.13.005 of August 14, 2013, where six strategic lines were included, which were the result of the identification of actors in the participation processes; environmental, social and participatory diagnosis and regional vision in more than 13 working tables throughout the jurisdiction in which more than 400 people were present, which were reflected in more than 34 actors.

Action Plan (PAC): This is the planning instrument of the Regional Autonomous Corporations, which specifies their institutional commitment to achieve the objectives and goals set forth in the PGAR. It defines the actions and investments to be carried out in the area under its jurisdiction and its projection corresponds to the administration period (4 years).

Currently, the Action Plan called "A pact for our land" 2020-2023 is in force. To achieve this Pact for Our Land, the PAC is based on the synthesis of both the environmental conditions of the territory of Corporinoquia's jurisdiction, as well as the management of the entity in the exercise of its functions; to analyze the progress achieved so far, thus recognizing the challenges that remain to be met and thus raise the strategies and operational actions that direct this action plan towards the great challenge of conservation and sustainable use of natural ecosystems.

Watershed management plans (Pomca): Zoning and describing strategies for conservation and sustainable use of watershed resources.

In Corporinoquia's jurisdiction, the Pomca emphasize the control of agricultural, industrial and urban expansion.

Corporinoquia has 21 regulated POMCAS, of which 15 are in force and have been updated through different contractual processes.

Water Resource Management Plan (PORH): "The Water Resource Management Plan (PORH) is the planning instrument that allows the environmental authority to intervene systemically in water bodies to ensure the quality and quantity conditions required to sustain aquatic ecosystems and the current and potential uses of these water bodies" (Technical Guide for the Formulation of Water Resource Management Plans- MADS, 2014).

According to the provisions of Decree 1076 of 2015 (Article 2.2.2.3.3.3.1.4), the Environmental Authorities must carry out the Water Resource Management in order to determine the classification of water flows, generically set their destination for different uses and the possibilities of exploitation.

Corporinoquia has these PORH:

    - Caño Aguaclara Management and Regulation Plan.

    - Surface Water Resource Management Plan for the Garubana Stream located in the Municipality of Aguazul.

    - Surface Water Resource Management Plan For The Upia Stream Located In The Municipality Of Villanueva

    - Surface Water Resource Management Plan For The La Comarca Stream Located In The Municipality Of Villanueva

    - Surface Water Resource Management Plan For La Quebrada La Quinchalera Stream Located In The Municipality Of Sabanalarga

    - Surface Water Resource Management Plan For Caño Grande Stream Located In The Municipality Of Monterrey

    - Management Plan Of The Superficial Water Resource Of The Palmar River, Regulation Of The Mercadillo Creek, Hydrographic Sub-zone Of The Guayuriba River.

    - Regulation, Water Resource Management Plan And The Quality Objectives Of The Caño La Colorada Microbasin In The Municipality Of Monterrey

    - Regulation Of The Water Resource Of The Quebrada La Guaza Microbasin, Jurisdiction Of The Choachi And Ubaque Municipality, Department Of Cundinamarca

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (INSTITUTIONAL CHARACTERS)
pill.content:
Corporinoquia has created six (6) institutional characters that accompany and teach the children in its jurisdiction, which are known as:

1. Régulo Palma: He is a Moriche grandfather of an average age of 50 years who lives in the floodable savannas of the departments of Arauca, Casanare and Vichada. His name (Régulo) comes from the function of water regulation that he plays in the Ecosystems and his last name comes from the species (Palma) that identifies him. He is a spokesman to make known the wonderful water resource of the Orinoquia, its main mission is to ensure the care, conservation and protection of water.

2. Grandma Tita: She represents a woman over 60 years old, in love with the flora of the Orinoquia, with ancestral and natural knowledge about the rich ecosystem that inhabits the region. She is the spokeswoman and expert to make known important aspects for the conservation of the flora species, she teaches their names, main characteristics and the richness of the biodiversity of the territory that are from the perpetual snows of the snowy Cocuy, passing through the cloud forests of the department of Boyacá and Cundinamarca and go into the foothills of the plains, reaching the flooded savannas of Casanare, Arauca and Vichada. She also invites us to know some ecosystemic benefits that represent us, her age allows her to speak from experience and also invites us to know the medicinal benefits of plants. In addition, her wisdom and love for the family allows her to give some prevention tips for risk management in the territory. She is the official spokesperson to talk about natural catastrophes.

3. Ara: She is a young Araucanian woman proud of her department, which is why she carries the initials (Arauca) in her name. Her average age is 25 years old, her personality is cheerful, she is an environmentalist, ecologist, her main interest is the care of the environment through the correct management of the classification of solid waste. She is convinced that with recycling and the correct separation of waste we can save the planet, her favorite words are Reduce, Recycle and Reuse and with this she seeks that each of the inhabitants of the jurisdiction put into practice the classification tips, generating awareness, she is sure that individual responsibility for the environment, generates great changes in the region.

4. Chigüi: He is a beautiful mammal, funny, very cheerful and is called the king of the flooded savannahs in the Orinoquia, he is the spokesman to talk about wildlife, being the king of the savannah and dense forests, he knows all the species that inhabit the Orinoquia. He is very social and always lives in a herd, he has a tireless fight against illegal wildlife trafficking in the region. He is in charge of ensuring that the species live in their natural habitat, free and happy in the magical ecosystems of the five departments of Corporinoquia's jurisdiction. Representative species of the Eastern Plains.

5. Quira: It is a beautiful and colorful female hummingbird, responsible for the balance of the jurisdiction, from the air is who watches over the territory and fills it with peace. Her age is that of an adult female, with a beautiful personality, she is calm, free, serene and very conciliatory. She represents a good soul, which is reflected in the great human beings who work in the corporation and the beautiful animal species that inhabit the jurisdiction, she is practical and very intelligent. In her is the essence of the mission of Corporinoquia, she is the one who has the main vision of conservation and preservation of ecosystems, in her personality is reflected the commitment and love for which we work to realize the Covenant for Our Earth.

6. Quito: He is a child of explorer and adventurous spirit, his main interest is to publicize the actions for climate change mitigation and rational use of energy. His personality is risky and very extroverted, his age is twelve years old, and his investigative and explorer spirit makes him take on different challenges in the management of climate change. His personality reflects learning values such as solidarity and helping the community. He is an official spokesperson for energy saving habits and their rational use.

pill.title: Curiosities
pill.content:
Did you know that...

CORPORINOQUIA is integrated by the territorial entities of jurisdiction, which by their characteristics geographically constitute the same ecosystem; besides being endowed with administrative and financial autonomy, own patrimony and legal personality, in charge of administering within its jurisdiction the environment and renewable natural resources.

pill.title: INTRODUCTION (Welcome)
pill.content:
Welcome, did you know that the plains piedmont is an important area for being the transition between the mountain ecosystems and the savannah, this condition has endowed it with a great diversity of species, landscapes and social dynamics.

Watch video: Between savannah and foothills we will know the flora of the Orinoquia  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PJMSp8W7jYM

Among the main causes of biodiversity loss are fragmentation (loss of continuity of an ecosystem), degradation (loss of natural environmental conditions) and loss of natural connectivity caused by the expansion of the agricultural frontier, land use change, deforestation and overexploitation of natural resources. Given this scenario, maintaining ecosystems and the natural connectivity between them becomes an essential task for the conservation of biodiversity and the services it provides.

Among the strategies that Corporinoquia has considered for the conservation of bio-diversity is the creation of protected areas, which must be complemented with specific actions that guarantee the functionality of the landscapes (matrix) in which they are inserted, so that they maintain connectivity and the flow of energy and services, one of these actions are the biological corridors.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (WHAT IS BIODIVERSITY?)
pill.content:
According to the Convention on Biological Diversity, the term biodiversity or biological diversity refers to the variety of living organisms of any kind. This variety can be expressed in terms of different species, variability within a single species, or the existence of different ecosystems. An ecosystem is the basic functional unit of nature. It comprises living organisms, the non-living environment, and their interrelationships.

Colombia has more than 54,000 species registered in the Global Biodiversity Information Infrastructure (GBIF), sharing with Brazil the first place in the world in terms of biodiversity and is identified by the United Nations Environment Program as one of the 17 megadiverse countries that host 70% of the world's biodiversity in only 10% of the territory.

(Video: Biodiversity)

https://youtu.be/Rh4txXeKlME?si=7fka8n_jT7TMndZZ

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (IMPORTANT DATA ON BIODIVERSITY IN COLOMBIA)
pill.content:
Currently, in terms of biodiversity, Colombia is:

    ➢ The first country in diversity of birds and orchids.

    ➢ The second country in diversity of plants, amphibians, river fish and butterflies.

    ➢ The third country in diversity of reptiles and palms.

    ➢ The fourth country in mammal diversity.

Colombia is also characterized by the importance of natural forests, which cover 53% of the continental national territory and concentrate more than half of the terrestrial animal and plant species.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (WHAT ARE ECOSYSTEM SERVICES?
pill.content:
Ecosystem services have been defined as the benefits that humans obtain from ecosystems, whether economic or cultural. Biodiversity supports a wide variety of them which can be:

    ➢ Supporting services, e.g. soil formation, nutrient cycling, primary production.

    ➢ Provisioning services, e.g., food, drinking water, firewood, fiber, biological chemicals, genetic resources. The most emblematic case         in Colombia is probably that of the páramos, ecosystems that represent less than 2% of the Colombian territory but provide water to         70% of the population.

    ➢ Regulatory services, e.g., climate regulation, disease regulation, water regulation, water purification, pollination.

    ➢ Cultural services, e.g., spiritual and religious, recreation and ecotourism, aesthetics, inspiration, education, location, cultural heritage.

All of these benefits to society are made possible by biodiversity and its ecosystems, and the well-being of present and future generations on the planet depends on them.

(More information on ecosystem services at: https://www.fao.org/ecosystem-services-biodiversity/es/)

(Video projection: Ecosystem Services, our vital connection to biodiversity: https://youtu.be/2h6rOS8NvkQ?si=mV4a2i3-W9VCPJtW)

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (PÁRAMO ECOSYSTEM)
pill.content:
The páramo is considered a humid tropical ecosystem normally located above the upper forest limit (Castañeda, 2016; Hofstede et al., 2014), dominated by herbaceous and shrub vegetation (Crespo et al., 2009) and with cold bioclimatic landscapes (above 3,200 m a.s.l. and its highest peak is at 5,493 masl) (Castañeda, 2016) (Castañeda, 2016). The páramo is not only a tropical high mountain ecosystem, but also a production and work space with great history, culture and politics (Hofstede et al., 2014; Serrano & Galárraga, 2015).

The páramos are considered strategic ecosystems especially for their role in the regulation of the hydrological cycle that sustains the supply of water resources for human consumption and development of economic activities of more than 70% of the Colombian population, these territories are also characterized by their high biotic and sociocultural richness.

(Video: Get to know Colombia's páramos: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZiVLYsyqtUM)

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (CHARACTERISTIC SPECIES OF FLORA AND FAUNA: FLORA)
pill.content:
Regarding the biodiversity of the páramos, it is better defined as unique rather than rich, as it has a high level of endemism and specialization, both at the genetic and landscape levels, promoted by its isolated and fragmented occurrence (Castro, 2011).

In this region there is a vegetation of grasses, shrubs, herbs, tundra and peat. There are low trees with permanent leaves, lichens, mosses and grasses.

Among the main species of flora of the páramo are the following:

    - The frailejón (Espeletia hartwegiana).

    - Páramo moss (Sphagnum sp).

    - The páramo star (Paepalanthus alpinus).

    - The seven red leather (Tibouchina grossa).

    - The flowers of Thristerix sp.

    - The blue phytophthora (Centaurea sp).

    - The alstroemerias.

    - Moor arnica (Senecio formosus).

    - Purple tobacco (Nicotiana sp).

    - Bromeliads (Puya sp).

    - The chuscales (Chusquea scandens)

    - The macolla (Calamagrostis effusa)

    - Chocho (Lupinus tolimensis)

    - Sanalotododo (Baccharis tericuneata)

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (CHARACTERISTIC SPECIES OF FLORA AND FAUNA: FAUNA)
pill.content:
Some of the most representative animals of the moorlands are:

    - Copetón (Zonotrichia capensis)

    - Andean Condor (Vultur gryphus)

    - Páramo Barbudito (Oxypogon guerinii)

    - Hummingbirds (Eriocnemis vestita, Lesbia victoriae, Pterophanes cyanopterus, Coeligena heliantea)

    - Paramuna Pipit (Anthus bogotensis)

    - Tanager (Diglossa lafresnayii, Anisognathus igniventris)

    - Collared Magpie (Cyanolyca armillata)

    - Paramund Sparrow (Geospizopsis unicolor)

    - Paramund Duck (Anas andium)

    - Tinajo (Cuniculus taczanowskii)

    - Spectacled bear (Tremarctos ornatus)

    - Frogs (Atelopus carrikeri, Pristimantis sp, Dendropsophus luddeckei )

    - Butterflies (Vanessa sp, Greta sp, Altinote sp, Dione sp, Steremnia sp, Pedaliodes sp)

    - Tigrillos (Leopardus sp)

    - Foxes Lycalopex culpaeus

    - Tapir (Tapirus pinchaque)

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (MOST RELEVANT ECOSYSTEM SERVICES)
pill.content:
The páramos possess great biodiversity and provide several ecosystem services of great importance at the biological, hydrological, social, cultural and economic levels (Ayala et al., 2014); for example, water regulation, carbon sequestration, soil protection, biodiversity conservation, among others (Calderón et al., 2013; Farley et al., 2011).

Category *  Concept Perceived elements
Ecosystem Provisioning Services (EES) Tangible assets that support Water, firewood, straw, food, medicinal plants.
Regulatory ecosystem services (SER) Benefits influencing quality of life Clean air, water regulation and sanitation.

 

Category *  Concept Perceived elements
Cultural ecosystem services (CES) Direct and indirect contact with the ecosystem. Scenic beauty, beautiful fauna and flora, tranquility, site identity, heritage.
Supporting ecosystem services (SES) Functions that favor the development of ecological and biological processes. Soil formation, nutrient recycling, photosynthesis.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (HIGH ANDEAN FOREST ECOSYSTEM)
pill.content:
The Andean Forests are mountain ecosystems, with a wide range of elevation; they are framed between 2,000 m.a.s.l. and 3,500 m.a.s.l., they are located in the Andes mountain range, in cold and very cold lands, between 12 and 17.5 ° C.

(Video: It's time for the Andean forests https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RDORMVTi4kk)

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (CHARACTERISTIC SPECIES OF FLORA AND FAUNA: FLORA)
pill.content:
The forest canopy is formed by the canopy of myrtles (Luma apiculata), amarraboyos (Meriania nobilis), sarros ferns (Cyathea microdonta), chagualos (Clusia sp), sietecueros (Andesanthus lepidotus) and several species of palms (macana (Wettinia kalbreyeri), among others). Some plants grow over others and sometimes strangle them, as do the matapalos and other species. Some emergent trees stand out from the canopy, such as oaks (Quercus humboldtii), laurels (Laurus nobilis), encenillos (Weinmannia tomentosa), chaquiros (Retrophyllum rospigliosii), bear's paw (Oreopanax incisus) and wax palms.

And a variety of epiphytes, mosses (Sphagnum spp ), lichens, orchids, bromeliads, araceae, ferns (Selaginellas).

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (CHARACTERISTIC SPECIES OF FLORA AND FAUNA: FAUNA)
pill.content:
In the high Andean forest live, among others, Andean bears - also known as spectacled bears (Tremarctos ornatus) -, wolf guaguas (Cuniculus paca), cusumbos (Nasuella olivácea), white-tailed deer (Odocoileus virginianus), bush dogs and foxes (Lycalopex culpaeus). Several species of butterflies, such as the glass butterfly (Greta sp), the mirror butterfly (Agraulis sp.), as well as moths, bees, wasps, beetles, and stick insects, fly gently and slowly along the edges of the forest and on the banks of the streams.

Several arachnids also live there, among them some species of spiders, tarantulas and scorpions; some snakes, most of them hunters, such as the "tierreras" or "bobas" (Atractus crassicaudatus), the black hunter, the "juetiadora" or "lomo de machete" (Chironius flavopictus) and the cold ground viper (Atractus crassicaudatus), "colgadora" or "granadilla" (Spilotes pullatus); There are also several species of frogs, such as the so-called glass frogs (Centrolenidae sp), which sing at dusk, and many species of birds and birds, such as the Copetón (Zonotrichia capensis), Andean Condor (Vultur gryphus), Barbudito de Páramo (Oxypogon guerinii), Hummingbirds (Eriocnemis vestita, Lesbia victoriae, Pterophanes cyanopterus, Coeligena heliantea), Blackbirds (Mimus gilvus, Turdus fuscater), Emerald toucan (Aulacorhynchus prasinus), Owls (Ciccaba albitarsis, Megascops choliba), Mountain guan (Penelope sp).

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (MOST RELEVANT ECOSYSTEM SERVICES)
pill.content:
The Andean forest is one of the main providers of ecosystem services among the most representative are:

Maintaining the habitat of animals and plants: the biodiversity of the forest is very high and presents a large number of species that in some cases are endemic. Intrinsically, the forest's biodiversity reflects several services it provides, such as shelter for species, including endemic species, habitat maintenance and regeneration, provision of medicinal plants (Bubb, May, Miles, & Sayer, 2004), ornamental plants, raw material for handicrafts, pollination or timber uses (Armenteras, Cadena, & Moreno, 2007).

Water supply: plays an important role in the hydrological cycle since it acts as a regulating agent maintaining water sources (Armenteras, Cadena, & Moreno, 2007), it also regulates river flows helping to control and maintain water flows during dry times (Tobón, 2009).

Water from forests is used for agricultural production (irrigation water), livestock, industry, energy generation, human consumption, recreation, etc. (Armenteras, Cadena, & Moreno, 2007).

Carbon sequestration: High Andean forests are also of utmost importance in the provision of services such as carbon sequestration and fixation (Bubb, May, Miles, & Sayer, 2004) and the regulation and participation in the natural cycles of nutrients such as nitrogen and phosphorus (Caballero-Rueda, Rodríguez, & Martín, 1997).

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (PIEDMONT ECOSYSTEM)
pill.content:
The piedmont of the plains is variously defined by several authors, some of whom state that it is a region that lies between 50 and 1100 meters above sea level in the eastern part of the eastern cordillera of the Andean mountain system (Becerra, 2009), while others indicate that it lies below 1000 meters above sea level in the same mountain range (Alexander Von Humboldt Institute, 2009).

However, all of these define it as an area of great ecosystem diversity and of vital importance for the inhabitants of the region.

(Video: Biodiversity Conservation in the Piedemonte Llanero https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7cNiSyMNDns)

This ecosystem constitutes a biological corridor of transitory species between the Amazon, Orinoquia and the Andean mountain system, such as the Jaguar (Alexander Von Humboldt Institute, 2009). The main characteristic of the piedmont are the tall, dense and diverse forests, developed on the gently sloping plains to the east of the glaciers, which extend to the foot of the eastern margin of the Andes Mountains in their contact with the Amazonian plains.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (CHARACTERISTIC SPECIES OF FLORA AND FAUNA: FLORA)
pill.content:
Some of the most representative species of this ecosystem are:

    - Caruto - Genipa americana

    - Cress Cumin - Aniba perutilis

    - Plum tree - Spondias mombin

    - Caimarón - Pourouma cecropiifolia Mart

    - Cacay - Caryodendron orinocense

    - Avichure - Couma macrocarpa Barb

    - Frijolillo - Abarema jupunba

    - Orchid - Peristeria violácea

    - Saman - Samanea saman

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (CHARACTERISTIC SPECIES OF FLORA AND FAUNA: FAUNA)
pill.content:
Some of the most representative species of this ecosystem are:

    - Hummingbird - Chlorostilbon poortmanni

    - Jacamará - Brachygalba goeringi

    - Juan bobo - Hypnelus ruficollis Espinero - Phacellodomus rufifrons

    - Flycatcher - Phelpsia inornata

    - Yellow-cheeked bogeyman - Vireolanius eximius

    - Jaguar - Panthera onca

    - Four nosed - Bothrops atrox

    - Coporo - Prochilodus mariae

    - Jumper - Salminus hilarii

    - Red-tailed squirrel - Sciurus granatensis

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (MOST RELEVANT ECOSYSTEM SERVICES)
pill.content:
The piedmont ecosystem, thanks to its great biodiversity, contributes significantly to the following ecosystem services:

- Support Services: Support services are those that have the function of maintenance on the ecosystem itself, they are services necessary for the production of other ecosystem services (Valdez, 2011). In this sense, the ecosystem support services provided by the Piedemonte are divided into 5 functions, which are:

    - Maintaining biodiversity

    - Soil formation

    - Genetic material

    - Pollination

    - Nutrient supply.

- Regulatory Services: Regulating services are those obtained from the regulation of the ecosystem itself (Valdez, 2011), for example, carbon storage. In this sense, the ecosystem support services provided by the piedmont are divided into 5 main functions:

    - Water resource

    - Climate regulation

    - Climate change regulation and mitigation

    - Gas regulation

    - Moisture retention

    - Waste treatment and regulation.

- Provisioning Services: Provisioning services are those that are obtained directly from the ecosystem such as timber, water resources, food, raw materials, energy and minerals, housing, and provision of shade and shelter.

- Cultural Services: Cultural services are those that provide non-material benefits obtained from the ecosystem such as an educational, recreational or tourism service (Valdez, 2011), such as:

    - Recreation and tourism

    - Cultural information

    - Spirituality

    - Shelter

    - Education

    - Ornamental elements

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (SAVANNA ECOSYSTEM)
pill.content:
The main characteristic of the Colombian savannah is that during eight months of the year it remains flooded, and the other four months are extremely dry and have an intertropical climate.

The region that preserves this ecosystem is bordered to the north and east by the Republic of Venezuela, to the south by the Amazon region of Colombia and to the west by the Eastern Cordillera (Andes mountain range) and includes the departments of Arauca, Casanare, Meta, Vichada and Norte del Guaviare (IGAC, 2008).

(Video: Get to know the savannas of the Orinoquia https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MUkbilNRwI8)

They are characterized by flat and concave topography with particularly low areas that correspond to lowlands and marshes that are flooded during the rainy season (floodable savannas).

Some representative economic activities are cattle ranching, oil exploitation and rice cultivation, as well as the recently introduced oil palm cultivation.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (CHARACTERISTIC SPECIES OF FLORA AND FAUNA: FLORA)
pill.content:
Some of the most representative species of this ecosystem are:

    - Hobo - Spondias mombin

    - Chirimiyo - Annona montana

pill.content:
Some of the most representative species of this ecosystem are:

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (MOST RELEVANT ECOSYSTEM SERVICES)
pill.content:
Savannas provide many environmental services, for example, the following:

Provisioning services: food production such as fish, seafood, livestock, soils for crops and water sources for human consumption.

Regulating and supporting services: water regulation in savannas, air quality with carbon sequestration, regulation of nutrient cycling, as well as surface water cycling, erosion control, productivity and climate change mitigation.

Support services: Savannas conserve and maintain biodiversity by providing shelter for many species of fauna, flora and fungi that contribute to the supply of nutrients and soil formation, thus contributing to the safeguarding of genetic material and promoting pollination.

Cultural services: recreation, education, and tourism, with activities such as sport fishing, bird watching, and ecological hikes. Resources for natural medicines and ancestral knowledge.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (CONSERVATION PLANS)
pill.content:
Next, we will show you some of the conservation plans that CORPORINOQUIA executes for the protection of fauna and flora species:

    ➢ Action plan for the protection of the Andean Bear (Tremarctos Ornatus):

    ➢ Structural biological corridor for the lowland tapir (Tapirus terrestres):

    ➢ Conservation and management plan for the white-tailed deer (odocoileus virginianus) in the jurisdiction of corporinoquia, specifically         in the municipalities of paz de ariporo, hato corozal, mani and tauramena in the department of Casanare.

    ➢ Conservation plan for the anteater anteater (myrmecophaga tridactyla) and the honey anteater (tamandua tetradactyla) for the         departments of arauca, casanare and vichada.

    ➢ "Conservation and management plan for mauritia flexuosa (moriche or cananguche) in the departments of casanare, arauca and         vichada jurisdiction of corporinoquia".

FOR YOUR INFORMATION!!!....

It should be noted that CORPORINOQUIA, in addition to these, carries out more conservation plans in other species of Fauna and Flora of great importance within the area of its jurisdiction, for more information about these plans you can request them directly to the Corporation or by the means of commination provided by the same Corporation.

question.question: Does the term biodiversity or biological diversity refer to the variety of living organisms of any kind, and can it also be expressed in terms of different species?

pill.title: Curiosities
pill.content:
Did you know that...

Colombia has more than 54,000 species registered in the Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF), sharing with Brazil the first place in the world in terms of biodiversity and is identified by the United Nations Environment Program as one of the 17 megadiverse countries that host 70% of the world's biodiversity in only 10% of the territory.

(Video: Biodiversity https://youtu.be/Rh4txXeKlME?si=7fka8n_jT7TMndZZ)

pill.content:
1. Clean waters and living watersheds

    1.1. The water basin as a system

        1.1.2. Ecosystem services in a watershed

    1.2. Colombia's watersheds

        1.2.1. What is a macro watershed?

        1.2.2. How many macro-watersheds are there in the country?

    1.3. Strategic macro-basin plans

        1.3.1. Importance of macro-basin strategic plans

    1.4. Water resource management - Corporinoquia

        1.4.2. Water Resource Management Plan

pill.title: INTRODUCTION (Welcome)
pill.content: Hello!... Welcome to the thematic content "Cuencas Vivas", here you can find everything related to watersheds, i.e. its definition, classifications, regulations, ecosystem services and the importance of taking care of this water resource that also benefits the other natural resources (soil, air, fauna and flora) in ecosystems.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (THE RIVER BASIN AS A SYSTEM)
pill.content:
A watershed is defined as the area of surface or groundwater that flows into a hydrographic network with one or more natural watercourses; these can be of continuous or intermittent flow, which converge in a larger course, which in turn can flow either into a main river, a natural water reservoir, a swamp or directly into the sea (Ministry of Environment and Sustainable Development, 2014).

However, the watershed is a complex system composed of physical elements such as geological structure, water resources, climate and soils; biological elements such as flora, fauna and ecosystems; as well as anthropogenic, cultural, socioeconomic and institutional elements, which are deeply interrelated and, as a whole, confer particular characteristics (Tapia, 1994).

It should be pointed out that watersheds are like our circulatory system, in which veins and arteries function as networks to transport blood from the tissues to the lungs. A watershed can be made up of several sub-watersheds, which in turn are made up of micro-watersheds.

(Video: What is a watershed?: https://youtu.be/ZS4dn0l41YY?si=- kj93HlOrCXktSAU)

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (PARTS OF A RIVER BASIN)
pill.content:
Upper watershed: it is located in the upper part of the mountains and is where the river originates. Normally in this area there is a steeper slope and the small strands of water that flow move at high speed. The water is colder and has a low concentration of nutrients. There we find a high diversity of organisms, mostly of small size. In this zone many species feed on the leaves that fall into the water from the trees along the river.

Middle basin: the slope is reduced and the volume of water in the river, the temperature and the concentration of nutrients in the water increase. This zone is normally the site of most agricultural and livestock activities.

Low basin: located at low altitudes and flat areas, the water velocity is reduced, nutrient concentrations increase and the water is more turbid. This zone is normally subject to the greatest fishing activity. Colombia is also characterized by the importance of natural forests, which cover 53% of the national continental territory and account for more than half of the country's terrestrial animal and plant species.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (ECOSYSTEM SERVICES IN A WATERSHED)
pill.content:
Water supply for domestic, agricultural and industrial consumption is one of the main ecosystem services provided by the rivers, streams and creeks that are part of a watershed.

Agriculture and food security depend to a large extent on surface water and sediments transported through the watersheds, and they also provide hydroelectric power.

A watershed in a good state of conservation regulates surface runoff, prevents and reduces flooding and the risk of landslides, provides natural resources for the development of productive activities, and allows recreation and the enjoyment of an attractive landscape.

It should be noted that watersheds are a space for the productive, social and cultural development of society and a habitat for fauna and flora.

(Video: What is a river basin and integrated water resources management: https://youtu.be/EeWdvJrdPpU?si=Asflx3h8Wg5sAebI)

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (WATERSHEDS OF COLOMBIA)
pill.content:
What is a macro watershed?

According to IDEAM (IDEAM, 2013), hydrographic areas or macrobasins correspond to hydrographic regions or watersheds. These areas are large regions that group basins and rivers that flow into the same sea.

How many macro basins are there in the country?

Colombia has a dense hydrographic network of more than 700,000 micro-basins, which are physically defined in five large hydrographic regions (Minagriculture and FAO 2014). The first four (4) that strictly comply with the definition of watershed, these are: i) Orinoco, ii) Amazon, iii) Atlantic (Caribbean) and iv) Pacific.

The fifth hydrographic area was defined based on its importance in the socioeconomic context of the country, this is v) Magdalena-Cauca.

(Video: Watersheds in Colombia, understanding and interpreting the management through the landscape: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d2t0ajTeJcA)

Corporinoquia's jurisdiction is located in the Orinoco Hydrographic Area, which in turn is divided into 59 Hydrographic Subzones established to facilitate the management and administration of water resources.

The following is a visualization of its jurisdiction:

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (MACROBASIN STRATEGIC PLANS)
pill.content:
The EMPs are a "long-term environmental planning instrument that, with a national vision, constitutes the framework for the formulation, adjustment and/or execution of the different policy, planning, planning, management, and follow-up instruments existing in each of them".

For the elaboration of these Plans, the following phases are developed:

    ➢ Baseline: includes the analyses of available technical, scientific, economic, social and environmental information and identification         of  actors involved in the planning of the natural resources of the Macrobasin, as well as the main conflicts and unintentional         natural and anthropic risks related to natural resources.

    ➢ Diagnosis: Involves the identification and evaluation of factors and variables that affect the development of the Macrobasin,         associated with changes in the state of the water resource and other natural resources.

    ➢ Strategic analysis: Addresses the process of agreeing on the desired model for the respective macro-basin, based on which the         guidelines and directives for the integrated management of water and other natural resources are defined.

    ➢ Strategic agreements and actions: includes the definition of agreements, actions and investments that may be implemented by         each of the key stakeholders.

(Video: Macrobasin Strategic Plans-POMCAS https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I2gt69qAa00)

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (IMPORTANCE OF STRATEGIC MACROBASIN PLANS)
pill.content:
The Strategic Plan of the respective Macrobasin constitutes the framework for:

    ➢ The formulation of the new Basin Ordination and Management Plans (POMCAS) within the Macrobasin, as well as, for the         adjustment of those that have already been formulated.

    ➢ The formulation of the Management Plans of the Marine-Coastal and Oceanic Environmental Units, as well as for the adjustment of         those already formulated.

    ➢ The formulation of the Environmental Management Plans for Micro-basins and aquifers, as well as for the adjustment of those that         have already been formulated.

    ➢ The structuring of the national water resource monitoring network.

    ➢ The formulation of regional and/or local sectoral public policies.

    ➢ The formulation of the new four-year action plans of the regional environmental authorities, in accordance with the obligations         stipulated in Decree 1200 of 2004 and other regulatory norms.

    ➢ Establish criteria and guidelines for the hydrological management of the main rivers of the Macrobasin by the environmental         authorities, in terms of quantity and quality, as well as water uses at the subarea level.

    ➢ Establish strategies and actions to improve the governance of water resources and other natural resources in the Macrobasin.

In the following section, the POMCAS will be discussed in more detail.

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (CORPORINOQUIA POMCAS)
pill.content:
The POMCA is the planning instrument through which the coordinated use of soil, water, flora and fauna and the management of the basin is planned.

The country has 396 river basins subzones and subsequent level (394 continental and San Andres and Providencia) that are subject to planning and management, in accordance with the provisions of the Single Regulatory Decree of the Environment Sector Decree 1076 of 2015, which compiles among others Decree 1640 of 2012.

Corporinoquia in its jurisdiction has 21 regulated POMCAS, of which 15 are in force and have been updated through different contractual processes.

To learn more about Corporinoquia's current POMCAS follow the links below:

POMCA Ariporo: http://sigcloud.corporinoquia.gov.co/index.php/s/MA38e8CQ5qPLMwp

POMCA Caranal: http://sigcloud.corporinoquia.gov.co/index.php/s/sBaEJTYSRwyWSec

POMCA Cravo Sur: http://sigcloud.corporinoquia.gov.co/index.php/s/LCiAgAf9i9f2MPL

POMCA Cusiana: http://sigcloud.corporinoquia.gov.co/index.php/s/rZAk2zk3X44q8kW

Bita River POMCA: http://sigcloud.corporinoquia.gov.co/index.php/s/rHxGmxCS3MCMZJZ

POMCA Ele River: http://sigcloud.corporinoquia.gov.co/index.php/s/GYgrjMsJ8KNeqRQ

Guavio River OMWP: http://sigcloud.corporinoquia.gov.co/index.php/s/pRHgiRsxxsN5rNm

Guayuriba River POMCA: http://sigcloud.corporinoquia.gov.co/index.php/s/4wt8xwiqwYbtync

POMCA Tua River: https://sig.corporinoquia.gov.co/waportal/apps/sites/#/portalide/pages/pomca s

POMCA Tacuya: http://sigcloud.corporinoquia.gov.co/index.php/s/4wytRbbfKNd95sc

The following map shows the location of the 21 POMCAS:

The environmental zoning of the POMCAs is presented below:

pill.title: THEMATIC DEVELOPMENT (WATER RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLAN)
pill.content:
Water resource management is a planning instrument that affects the administration of inland surface water resources and allows the competent environmental authority to set the destination and use of inland surface water bodies, establish the standards, conditions and monitoring program to achieve and maintain the potential uses of water, as well as to preserve biological cycles and the normal development of species, over a minimum ten-year horizon.

The following is Corporinoquia's water resource management plan for 9 water sources:

pill.content:
Did you know that...

Watersheds are like our circulatory system, in which veins and arteries function as networks to transport blood from the tissues to the lungs. A watershed can be made up of several sub-watersheds, which in turn are made up of micro-watersheds.

pill.title: Resources - Links of Interest
pill.content:
1. WEBSITE: Booklet 8. Chair of education for environmental culture. Water module.

Link:https://www.cornare.gov.co/EducacionAmbiental/catedra/moduloagua/Octavo_Agua.pdf

2. WEB SITE: Booklet 9. Local organization for the social management of water and watersheds.

Link:https://docplayer.es/75648619-Cartilla-9-la-organizacion-localpara-la-gestion-social-del-agua-y-cuencas.html

3. WEB SITE: Basins subject to instrumentation and monitoring (hydrographic zones).

Link: https://www.minambiente.gov.co/gestion-integral-del-recursohidrico/cuencas-objeto-instrumentacion-y-monitoreo-zonashidrograficas/

questions_pill.question: Is a river basin defined as the area of surface water or groundwater discharging into a hydrographic network with one or more natural watercourses?
Is the watershed a complex system composed of physical elements such as geological structure, water resources, climate and soils?
In the middle Basin does the slope decrease and the river water volume, temperature and nutrient concentration in the water increase?
What are the parts of a watershed?
According to the IDEAM (IDEAM, 2013), hydrographic areas or Macrobasins correspond to?
How many micro-watersheds exist in Colombia?
What does the acronym EMP stand for (an "environmental planning instrument")?
Is Corporinoquia's jurisdiction located in the Orinoco Hydrographic Area, which in turn is divided into 59 Hydrographic Subzones?
Aren't agriculture and food security highly dependent on surface water?
Is water supply for domestic, agricultural and industrial use an ecosystem service in a watershed?
Does a poorly maintained watershed regulate surface runoff, prevent and reduce flooding and landslide risk?
In this evaluation activity, you must select and drag the 4 (four) large hydrographic regions.
In this evaluation activity, you must select the parts of a river basin, then drag them to the image according to their location.
_________ hydrographic is the area of surface or groundwater discharging into a network __________ with one or more natural watercourses.
Low basin: located at altitudes ______ and flat areas, the speed of the _______ is reduced and the concentrations of ________ increase.
The _______ is a complex _______ composed of elements _______.
Middle basin: The ________ is reduced and the volume of _____ of the river, the _________ and the concentration of nutrients increase.
The __________ have multiple interactions both with humans and with the different groups of _______ and are therefore considered as a partner ecosystem.

posts.title: The alligator toom
posts.description: It tells the story of the caiman toom, an old and gigantic specimen that protects its eggs day and night from the terrible human claws, so that they can know the wonderful life that the tributary of the Orinoco offers them.
